awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Autonomous Underwater Power Distribution System for Continuous Operation
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER project responds to an urgent need to develop mobile power distribution systems that lower deployment and operating costs while simultaneously increasing network efficiency and response in dynamic and often dangerous physical conditions.  The significant need for an efficient and effective mobile power distribution system became evident during search and rescue/recovery missions following the Japan tsunami and the disappearance of the Malaysia MH370 airplane.  The technology outcomes from this project will apply to a broad range of environments (in space, air, water or on ground) where the success of long-term robotic network missions is measured by the ability of the robots to operate, for an extended period of time, in highly dynamic and potentially hazardous environments. These advanced features will provide the following advantages: efficiency, efficacy, guaranteed persistence, enhanced performance, and increased success in search/rescue/recovery/discovery missions.  

Specifically, this project addresses the following technology problems as it translates from research discovery toward commercial application: inflated energy use currently required when the autonomous vehicles break from mission to return to recharging station; lack of multi-robot coordination needed to take into account both fundamental hardware and network science challenges necessary to respond to energy needs and dynamic environment conditions. By addressing these gaps in technology, this work establishes the theoretical, computational, and experimental foundation for mobile power delivery and onsite recharging capability.  Moreover, the new technology developed in this project is universally adaptable for disparate autonomous vehicles especially autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs). In more technical terms, this project creates network optimization and formation strategies that will enable a power distribution system to reconfigure itself depending on the number of operational autonomous vehicles and recharging specifications to meet overall mission specifications, the energy consumption needs of the network, situational conditions, and environmental variables. Such a system will play a vital role in real-time controlled applications across multiple disciplines such as sensor networks, robotics, and transportation systems where limited power resources and unknown environmental dynamics pose major constraints. In addition to addressing technology gaps, undergraduate and graduate students will be involved in this research and will receive interdisciplinary education/ innovation/ technology translation/ outreach experiences through: developing efficient network energy routing, path planning and coordination strategies; designing and creating experimental test-beds and educational platforms; and engaging K-12th grade students in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math including those from underrepresented groups.  

This project engages Michigan Tech's Great Lake Research Center (GLRC) and Center for Agile Interconnected Microgrids (AIM) to develop experimental test-beds and conduct tests that validate the resulting methods and algorithms, and ultimately, facilitate the technology translation effort from research discovery toward commercial reality.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This work has created a reliable autonomous recharging system for autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) that enables continuous real-time marine observation and data collection in the presence of continuously changing underwater environmental circumstances. 

This research focused to overcome network science and technology challenges resulting in key contributions such as:

  • An agile modular underwater glider named ROUGHIE with increased maneuverability by a factor of 5 and decreased cost by a factor of 20 compared to available underwater gliders;
  • the first compact adaptable universal docking station for charging and data transfer undersea;
  • collaborative mission planning approach for multi-robot operations with energy replenishment and navigational strategies adaptable to changing conditions robust to disturbances and failures enabled with machine learning.

This project achievements in developing a cost-effective strategy for cooperative robotic deployment is critical for enabling long-term and long-distance operations. The low-cost mobile docking station together with mission planning and navigational algorithms will extend maritime sensing missions from days to months without the need for onsite human support, away from infrastructure, and at a lower cost. The developed tools and algorithms are universally adaptable, providing greater fleet versatility and adaptability over mission-specific marine system solutions.  This work will have great impact on not only US national security and Naval operations but also the democratization of science in challenging environments and surface-denied locations, such as the arctic. This CAREER project advanced convergent research to use sensor-equipped, persistent, and networked autonomous vehicles that will generate the comprehensive and real-time year-round data needed to manage marine ecosystems and responsive policy decisions effectively that impacts Billions of people worldwide.

In addition to the graduate and undergraduate students that conducted research, this project provided opportunity for hands-on project-based learning to and through college. The team developed inexpensive educational robotic platform, GUPPIE; Glider for Underwater Problem-solving and Promotion of Interest in Engineering. GUPPIE has been integrated into graduate-level, undergraduate-level, and pre-college class curricula to encourage engineering design practice. PI has actively created opportunities for broadening interest and participation in STEM fields. Mahmoudian has led collaborative efforts to develop a full co-robotics curriculum and hands-on activities engaging 2500 middle and high school students (at least 50% female) through one-day STEM festivals and week-long summer programs. This project also engaged middle school teachers and provided professional development opportunity for 6 teachers to take GUPPIE curriculum to their classroom. PI has developed new courses in undergraduate and graduate level on autonomous systems and concepts through lectures and hands-on implementation in the lab. The courses has been offered at two institutions and trained 180 engineers and prepared workforce for the autonomy and robotics related industry. 


Last Modified: 01/17/2023
Modified by: Nina Mahmoudian
